newsitem.title: UK: P&O's Sterling sees UK backing ferry merger.
newsitem.headline: P&O's Sterling sees UK backing ferry merger.

text.p: Lord Sterling, chairman of Britain's P&O, said on Thursday he believed the British government had already made clear that it would not object to P&O's plan for a ferry joint venture with Stena Line AB to compete with Eurotunnel's channel tunnel.

Refering to the government's decision earlier this year to lift specific bans on P&O Ferries cooperating with its rivals on the English Channel, Sterling told an analysts' meeting in London that the political attitude "has already been set".
"There is no way (the British) would hold it up...they said there must be strong competition with the tunnel".

Sterling said that he hoped the planned joint venture, which would be 60 percent owned by P&O and 40 percent by Stena, would change the competitive balance despite being much smaller in financial terms -- he described P&O Stena Line as a David to Eurotunnel's Goliath.
"There is no point in (ferries) fighting each other, what's important is to have a major competitor up against the tunnel in the years to come," he said.
Though he recognised that regulators would be focusing on the possible anti-competitve effect of the link, Sterling said he saw the situation as being beneficial for customers.
"The alternative for the consumer is you get an emasculated competitor that's on its back foot all the time... that can't be in the interests of the consumer," he said.

Looking at the likely issues to be addressed by regulators, Sterling added that the success in market terms of the Eurotunnel could not be ignored, saying, "The tunnel is a very dominant factor indeed."

The firms declined to detail the impact on profits or jobs of their outline merger plan but a P&O spokesman said it was likely that the crews on the two large ferries due to be taken out of service by the end of this year would be made redundant.
